items.label: The North part of America conteyning Newfoundland, New England, Virginia, Florida, New Spaine and Nova Francia, with ye riche Iles of Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica, and Porto Rieco, on the south, and upon ye west the large and goodly island of California

metadata.label: Title
metadata.value: The North part of America conteyning Newfoundland, New England, Virginia, Florida, New Spaine and Nova Francia, with ye riche Iles of Hispaniola, Cuba, Jamaica, and Porto Rieco, on the south, and upon ye west the large and goodly island of California

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: The first printed map in English to show California as an island, with flat northern coast.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Cities, etc. ; shoals; pictorial symbols; notes.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Notes on map refer to California, Sr. Thomas Button and Mr. Baffin.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: "852" & "853" inside neat line in top left & right corners of map.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Engraved by: R. Elstrake Sculpsit (lower right).

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: On the map are two notes, one stating"California sometymes supposed to be a part of ye westerne continent, but scince by a Spanish Charte taken by ye Hollanders it is found to be a goodly Ilande: the length of the west shoare beeing about 500 leagues..."

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Issued in: Hakluytus Posthumus or Purchas His Pilgrimes, III, 852-3. London, 1625, to accompany an article by H. Briggs on the Northwest Passage.

metadata.label: Relation
metadata.value: The Glen McLaughlin Map Collection of California as an Island

metadata.label: Title
metadata.value: Topographical Sketch of the Gold & Quicksilver District Of California, July 25th 1848. E. O. C. O. Lt. U.S.A. P.S. Duval's Lith. steam Press Phila

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: First accurate map to show the gold discoveries. In President Polk's Message to Congress, December 5, 1848, House Executive Document No.1, 30th Congress, Second Session. Wheat calls this "Most important of all the maps of 1848...of paramount importance in any cartographical consideration of the gold rush." See also Mason's two maps published with his report in the same volume.

metadata.label: Relation
metadata.value: David Rumsey Map Collection at Stanford University Libraries

items.description: First accurate map to show the gold discoveries. In President Polk's Message to Congress, December 5, 1848, House Executive Document No.1, 30th Congress, Second Session. items.label: Composite: Sheets Nos. 1-4, Irrigation Map of the San Joaquin Valley, California.

canvases.label: Composite: Sheets Nos. 1-4, Irrigation Map of the San Joaquin Valley, California.

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: Composite: Sheets Nos. 1-4, Irrigation Map of the San Joaquin Valley, California.

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Composite of the four sheets covering the entire San Joaquiin Valley.

metadata.label: Reference
metadata.value: California Water Atlas p 26( Reproduces sheet 3 ); Vogdes p 239.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: (Composite of) California State Engineering Department. Topographical And Irrigation Map Of The San Joaquin Valley. (Sheets Nos. 1-4). Wm. Ham. Hall, State Engineer, 1886. Note. This Topographical and Irrigation Map of San Joaquin Valley is published in four sheets, as follows: Sheet No. 1, from Tp. 4 N. to 1st Standard South. Sheet No. 2, from 1st to 3d Standard South. Sheet No. 3, from 3d to 5th Standard South. Sheet No. 4, from 5th to 8th Standard South. It is intended as a general illustration of the present extent of irrigation, and a means of studying its future possible development ...

metadata.label: Pub Title
metadata.value: California State Engineering Department. Topographical And Irrigation Map Of The San Joaquin Valley. (4 Continguous Sheets). Wm. Ham. Hall, State Engineer, 1886. Note. This Topographical and Irrigation Map of San Joaquin Valley is published in four sheets, as follows: Sheet No. 1, from Tp. 4 N. to 1st Standard South. Sheet No. 2, from 1st to 3d Standard South. Sheet No. 3, from 3d to 5th Standard South. Sheet No. 4, from 5th to 8th Standard South. It is intended as a general illustration of the present extent of irrigation, and a means of studying its future possible development ...

metadata.label: Pub Reference
metadata.value: California Water Atlas p 26( Reproduces sheet 3 ); Vogdes p 239.

metadata.label: Pub Note
metadata.value: A 4 sheet set. The sheets accompanied a report on irrigation issued by the State Engineering Department. The sheets show the areas of land that can be practically irrigated in the San Joaquin portion of the Central Valley. Classifies lands into several categories. Printed in full color. Mounted on linen. Relief depicted by contour lines in valley areas, and by hachures in the hills and mountains. Maps scanned from the collection of the Water Resources Center Archives, University of California Library.

items.label: World's pictorial line : birdseye view of the Pacific Slope

canvases.label: World's pictorial line : birdseye view of the Pacific Slope

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: World's pictorial line : birdseye view of the Pacific Slope

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Color pictorial map, on sheet 45x114, folded to 23 x 10. Title from cover, with 28 pages of text. On verso 24 pages of text "Sights and scenes in California", on recto text pages 25-28. Includes logo of "Union Pacific, the overland route" on cover. Map shows major cities, routes, rivers and mountains. Relief shown pictorially.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: World's pictorial line : birdseye view of the Pacific Slope reached via the Union Pacific, the overland route. Copyrighted. 1893, by E.L. Lomax, General passenger and ticket agent, Union Pacific System, Omaha, Neb. Knight, Leonard & Co., Printers and engravers, Chicago, Ill.

items.label: A Pictorial Map of Palo Alto and San Francisco Peninsula by Arthur Lites.

canvases.label: A Pictorial Map of Palo Alto and San Francisco Peninsula by Arthur Lites.

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: A Pictorial Map of Palo Alto and San Francisco Peninsula by Arthur Lites.

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Date estimated. A birdseye view map "drawn from the viewpoint of one aboard a United States Navy Dirigible" is bordered by vignette illustrations including a dirigible balloon or blimp at top right, "U.S. Naval Air Station at Sunnyvale Chosen for Favorable Climate". Other vignettes include "A Recreational Center on the Bay Front Under Construction" "Community Theatre", Stanford University buildings, California Redwood Park etc, with an historical figure in each corner. Map shows the buildings of Palo Alto and Stanford University, with San Francisco, Oakland and Berkeley at upper left, and Santa Clara and San Jose at right of center.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: A Pictorial Map of Palo Alto and San Francisco Peninsula by Arthur Lites.

metadata.label: Pub Title
metadata.value: Palo Alto, California. Palo Alto, A Pictorial Map Drawn from the View Point (Birdseye) of One Aboard a United States Navy Dirigible.

metadata.label: Pub Note
metadata.value: Double sided folding brochure. Date estimated. Elegant script on the verso promotes the area, with its perfect climate. Several versions of this pamphlet were issued over a period of years from the 1920s through the 1940s, and possibly later. This first edition has an image of a blimp with text "U.S. Naval Air Station at Sunnyvale" at upper right of the map. Several versions of this pamphlet were issued over a period of years from the 1920s through the 1950s.

items.label: Historic Road to Romance : California's Southern Empire tourist paradise

canvases.label: Historic Road to Romance : California's Southern Empire tourist paradise

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: Historic Road to Romance : California's Southern Empire tourist paradise

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Bird's eye view style pictorial map. The colorful design highlights missions and historical places, contemporary places and events in the region which includes San Bernardino County, Los Angeles County, Orange County, Riverside County, San Diego County, and Imperial County. With attractive border with vignette illustrating various historical events and places, including "First California Mission San Diego de Alcala 1769, and Cabrillo, 1542". Shows historic trails, roads, cities and towns, native American reservations, parks and points of interest. Includes decorative title cartouche and compass rose in yellow, blue and red. Relief shown pictorially.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: Historic Road to Romance : California's Southern Empire tourist paradise; cartography by Claude G. Putman. Research by Karl F. Brown. Copyright. 1946 by Road to Romance Assn. Inc.

items.label: The Panorama Today in Northern California

canvases.label: The Panorama Today in Northern California

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: The Panorama Today in Northern California

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Color pictorial mid-Century modern promotional map of Northern California, tell the history of the greater San Francisco Bay area. Showing vaqueros and missions; wagon trains and railroads; women at the beach and sailboats out at sea; eagles and skunks and deer and lots of cows and horses; fishing fleets; the Ferry Building; the UC Berkeley Campanile; Stanford University Hoover Tower; the Capitol building; large airplanes crossing the bay and grain elevators on the landscape. Also shows the Wine Regions of Napa Valley and Sonoma Valley, the agricultural regions of Sacramento and San Joaquin, the farm equipment and industrial agriculture buildings, and the images of Skiers near Lake Tahoe.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: The Panorama Today in Northern California its resources activities and opportunities. Published on its 100th. Anniversary by American Trust Company, San Francisco. Millard Sheets. Lithogravure in U.S.A.

metadata.value: The Panorama Today in Northern California its resources activities and opportunities. Published on its 100th. Anniversary by American Trust Company, San Francisco. Michael Shute. Lithoravure in U.S.A.

items.label: Cartoon Pen & Inklings of the Old Santa Clara Valley.

canvases.label: Cartoon Pen & Inklings of the Old Santa Clara Valley.

metadata.label: Short Title
metadata.value: Cartoon Pen & Inklings of the Old Santa Clara Valley.

metadata.label: Note
metadata.value: Signed by the artist. From notes by B. Ruderman: The map presents a lively historical look at the history of Santa Clara County, with a key locating 30 places, starting with Portola's first view of the Valley in 1769. Immediately below the Portola note is a bust of Leland Stanford and a construction site showing Stanford. In a lovely bit of political incorrectness, the note for Stanford states "Leland Stanford in 1881 made a luxuriant camp for a later tribe of Indians, the Stanford Reds." Ralph Rambo was a San Jose based Historian who wrote 14 books on the Santa Clara Valley. His books were extremely colorful and, according to the author, loosely recounted his experiences growing up during the pioneer days in the area. Ralph Rambo's profession was a graphic artist. He was the Art Director for Muirson Label Company for almost fifty years. His illustrations are quite vivid, often hand-lettered in an entertaining or comics fashion. He merged humor with history in order to convey historical value of his stories. A self-proclaimed "nostalgician," he could be compared with other social historians such as Herb Caen in San Francisco, California and "Petaluma Peopleologist," Bill Soberanes.

metadata.label: Full Title
metadata.value: Cartoon Pen & Inklings of the Old Santa Clara Valley.

metadata.label: Pub Title
metadata.value: Cartoon Pen & Inklings of the Old Santa Clara Valley.

metadata.label: Pub Note
metadata.value: Map is from a booklet which is not in this collection. Printed on brown ink on yellowish paper.
